factoid: Princess Mary threw uneasy glances at Natásha.
Natásha had a strong desire to have a tête‑à‑tête with Princess Mary.
Mademoiselle Bourienne remained in the room, talking about Moscow amusements.
Mademoiselle Bourienne also talked about theaters.
Mademoiselle Bourienne noticed hesitation in the anteroom.
Mademoiselle Bourienne was offended by hesitation.
Natásha felt offended by hesitation.
Natásha felt offended by Prince Andrew's nervousness.
Natásha felt offended by the unnatural manner of Princess Mary.
Natásha thought Princess Mary was making a favor by receiving her.
Everything that offended Natásha displeased Natásha.
Natásha did not like Princess Mary.
Natásha thought Princess Mary was very plain.
Natásha thought Princess Mary was affected.
Natásha thought Princess Mary was dry.
Natásha suddenly shrank into herself.
Natásha involuntarily assumed an offhand air.
The offhand air of Natásha alienated Princess Mary.
After five minutes of irksome, constrained conversation between Natásha and Princess Mary, they heard the sound of slippered feet rapidly approaching.
Princess Mary looked frightened.
The door opened.
Prince Andrew, wearing a dressing gown and a white nightcap, came in.
Prince Andrew addressed the woman as 'madam'.
Prince Andrew addressed the woman as 'Countess Rostóva'.
Prince Andrew said Prince Andrew was not mistaken about the identity of the woman.
Prince Andrew begged the woman to excuse him.
Prince Andrew repeated that Prince Andrew did not know.
Prince Andrew said 'God is my witness' in an unnaturally and unpleasant manner.
Prince Andrew said Prince Andrew did not know the woman had honored them with a visit.
Prince Andrew said Prince Andrew came in such a costume only to see his daughter.
Princess Mary stood with downcast eyes.
Princess Mary did not dare to look at Prince Andrew.
Princess Mary did not dare to look at Natásha.
Natásha, having risen and curtsied, did not know what to do.
Mademoiselle Bourienne smiled agreeably.
Prince Andrew muttered 'I beg you to excuse me, excuse me! God is my witness, I did not know.'
Prince Andrew looked Natásha over from head to foot.
Prince Andrew went out.
Mademoiselle Bourienne was the first to recover herself after Prince Andrew's apparition.
Mademoiselle Bourienne began speaking about Prince Andrew's indisposition.
Natásha looked at Princess Mary in silence.
Princess Mary looked at Natásha in silence.
The longer Natásha and Princess Mary looked at each other without speaking, the greater their antipathy grew.
Count Rostova returned.
Natásha was impolitely pleased when Count Rostova returned.
Natásha hastened to get away when Count Rostova returned.
Natásha hated the stiff, elderly Princess Mary at that moment.
Princess Mary could place Natásha in an embarrassing position.
Princess Mary spent half an hour with Natásha without mentioning Prince Andrew.
Natásha thought she could not begin talking about Prince Andrew in the presence of Mademoiselle Bourienne.
Princess Mary was tormented by the same thought that Natásha had.
Princess Mary knew what she ought to have said to Natásha.
Princess Mary was unable to say what she ought to have said because Mademoiselle Bourienne was in the way.
Princess Mary felt it very difficult to speak of the marriage.
When Count Rostova was leaving the room, Princess Mary hurriedly went up to Natásha.
Princess Mary took Natásha by the hand.
Princess Mary said something with a deep sigh.
Natásha glanced at Princess Mary ironi­cally without knowing why.
Princess Mary said 'Dear Natalie, I want you to know that I am glad my brother has found happiness.'
Princess Mary paused, feeling Princess Mary was not telling the truth.
Natásha noticed Princess Mary's pause.
Natásha guessed the reason for Princess Mary's pause.
Princess Mary said 'I think, Princess, it is not convenient to speak of that now.'
Princess Mary said it with external dignity and coldness.
Princess Mary felt tears choking Princess Mary.
Princess Mary thought 'What have I said and what have I done?' as soon as Princess Mary was out of the room.
They waited a long time for Natásha to come to dinner that day.
Natásha sat in Natásha's room crying like a child.
Natásha blew Natásha's nose.
Natásha was sobbing.
Sónya stood beside Natásha.
Sónya kissed Natásha's hair.
Sónya asked Natásha, 'Natásha, what is it about?'.
Sónya asked Natásha, 'What do they matter to you?'.
Sónya said 'It will all pass, Natásha'.
Sónya said 'But if you only knew how offensive it was... as if I...'.
Sónya told Natásha not to talk about it.
Sónya said it wasn't Natásha's fault so why should Natásha mind.
Natásha said 'I can’t tell you, I don’t know. No one’s to blame.'.
Natásha said 'It’s my fault.'.
Natásha said 'But it all hurts terribly.'.
Natásha said 'Oh, why doesn’t Prince Andrew come?'.
Natásha came in to dinner with red eyes.
Márya Dmítrievna knew how Prince Andrew had received the Rostóvs.
Márya Dmítrievna pretended not to notice how upset Natásha was.
Márya Dmítrievna jested resolutely and loudly at table.
Márya Dmítrievna jested with Count Rostova and other guests.
